contentItem.text: An elephant's trunk has more than 100000 muscles! A human body only has 639 muscles. The elephant can use it's trunk to do so many things from ripping branches off trees to picking up a single blade of grass! An elephant can hold a gallon of water in it's trunk before spraying it in it's mouth for a drink or on it's back to cool off.

Elephants eat up to 450 lbs (204 kilograms) of grass, fruit, bark, and acacia leaves a day and drink about 30 gallons (114 litres) of water a day. Elephants have sensitive skin so they protect it by spraying it with sand and mud to act as sunscreen and to cool down in the hot sun.

There are two different kinds of elephants. African elephants have ears the shape of the continent of Africa. African elephants have wrinkly skin and two "fingers" at the end of their trunk. Asian elephants are smaller, they have smoother skin and only one "finger" at the end of their trunk!

The low resounding calls elephants make can be heard by other elephants up to 5 miles (8 kilometers) away. Elephants use these calls to transmit information about danger, water and food. Adult elephants have no natural predators but lions and crocodiles can prey on the calves. Poaching and habitat loss are the biggest threat.

An elephant's trunk is so strong an adult male elephant can lift about 600 pounds (272 kilograms)! That means he could lift you and about 14 of your friends! The largest elephant on record was an adult male African elephant. It weighed about 24,000 pounds (10,890 kilograms) and was 13 feet (4 meters) tall at the shoulder!
